S3.T1.caption: Table 1: Example rules used to generate the data. Synonymous and antonymous rules are single word, while paraphrastic rules can contain multi-word expressions and grammatical constraints.
S3.T1.table:
Perturbation Example rules (source →→\to target)
Synonymous car →→\to automobile
refrigerator →→\to fridge
phone →→\to telephone
Paraphrastic performed in [NP] →→\to carried out within [NP]
be considered [NP] →→\to be viewed as [NP]
participating in [VP] →→\to taking part in [VP]
Antonymous open →→\to closed
wet →→\to dry
full →→\to empty

A2.T5.caption: Table 5: Neural modules of StackNMN and XNM. Here x𝑥x are the visual features, ctsubscript𝑐𝑡c_{t} is the textual parameter, each a𝑎a (and a^^𝑎\hat{a}) is an attention map over the image regions, z(t)superscript𝑧𝑡z^{(t)} is used to compute the final answer prediction, and all W𝑊W are learned parameters. For XNM, R𝑅R is the set of edge features and M𝑀M is the adjacency matrix of the scene graph.
